newsitem.title: FRANCE: Algeria grants licence to second private bank.
newsitem.headline: Algeria grants licence to second private bank.

text.p: Algeria's monetary authority, the Credit and Money Council, on Saturday granted a licence to allow the country's second fully private bank to operate.
"The council has approved the demand authorising the setting up of a private bank," said the official Algerian news agency APS quoting Algeria's central bank.
The new bank, named Commercial and Industrial Bank of Algeria, Banque Commerciale et Industrielle d'Algerie (BCIA), has a share capital of 500 million dinars ($8.9 million), APS said.
Algeria's first fully privately-owned bank, Union Bank, has been operating since last year.
Algeria, a gas and oil producing country, is moving to shift its once centrally commanded economy towards a free market.
The government passed legislation six years ago allowing private banks to compete with the country's five state owned banks.

Saudi's private bank Al Baraka joined forces with the Algerian state-owned Rural Development Bank of Algerie, Banque Algerienne de Developpement Rural, to set up a joint bank in Algiers in June 1991. (1$ =56 dinars)
